ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to talk about dance and movement in an educated way--something I definitely could not do before.

DEEP understanding of how movement influences writers, physicists, botanists, choreographers, creators. Super interesting topis about ethnography, dance, and the different ways of thinking about Movement. This class was especially relevant after restrictions from COVID-19 restricted movement. This class made me think about movement in a much larger view than Newton's laws or choreography. Although we were remote, Professor Coates did a wonderful job engaging the material to the medium we were/are in. This class was the first place I began to creatively consider how we can move beyond/within the Zoomsphere and how to break the Zoom mold.
New ways of thinking about body, dance, movement, research. New insights into artistic and scholarly approaches to research
I developed an understanding of dance and artistic movement, numerous frames of analysis for looking at the body in society, and tools for creative research of movement and bodies.

The discussion every week made me think about topics that start from human movements, like culture, environment, ethnography,notating, science, protest, etc. Through the class I started to understand movements in a different way, and to have a new vision of movements.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Collaboration and wide-range of students coming from different fields to encourage different types of conversation. Cross-Curricular topics. Guest lectures were PHENOMENAL.

Weakness: It was a movement-based research class on Zoom. Professor Coates did a great job engaging with this fact and working to create new experiences through the digital medium but at the ed of the day, it was a class on Zoom which is a huge weakness.

Weaknesses - slightly better organised class discussion and weekly assignments. I felt sometimes that, because we were pursuing our own interests, class lacked rigour 

Strengths - readings were really interesting. The structure of readings was also great. Every week my mind expanded a bit as new insights were added.

Professor Coates is an amazing teacher. She is patient and understanding, she cares for and is interested in her students, and teaches well across so many registers at once, guiding the class in synthesizing social science research, artistic practice, and personal experience into meaningful wholes.

I like the class structure a lot. It's very clear to have different topics every week along with readings, assignments, and in-class discussions. The readings are abundant and intriguing. The assignments are thoughtful and interesting. The discussions are engaging and thought-provoking.

The only weakness is that the class has to be in the virtual form. I'm curious about what the class will be like if we are in the dancing classroom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is one of the more difficult ones to translate to a virtual format. However, I think Prof. Coates did an incredible job at keeping us engaged and constantly learning given the limitations. She incorporated the physical and interactive elements of the class into her teaching, which I very much appreciated.
This class should have been in person. At least partially, I am afraid we lost of lot of engagement and experiential learning through having to stay in a digital platform.

This was the class in which I felt most physically present this semester. We took time to breathe, to be with each others bodies, and to experiment with all kinds of ways of emulating physical accompaniment through a screen.

It is challenging to move a movement class to Zoom. It would be better if the class can keep some in-person parts especially when we have the movement exercises in the class and I personally feel more comfortable have discussions in-person. There's one time a visiting artist asked us to go out and there's another time we're having break rooms and moving the computers around. It's nice to go out and move around during a Zoom class and maybe it's an interesting way to have class outside or while waling.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Prof. Coates is amazing! I would especially recommend this course to people who come from non-arts backgrounds, since the class was a great introduction into a new way of thinking.

YES! This really is a wonderful course, my only caveat is that I wish I could have had the experience to take it in person.  This class is foundational to how I think about Movement as a choreographer, and extremely valuable to ANY physicist/ethnographer/creator/dancer/artist.
I would but it would be better in person than over Zoom.
Yes! This course is an awesome chance to explore bodies and movement, and to learn how to do creative research in just about any direction you can imagine.
Yes. I think this class is a great choice for art school students. It provides lots of new thoughts to my own practices, and can be inspiring for students from different programs.
